messageBody:
Tom Roche Thu, 1 Sep 2005 20:28:00 -0400
>>>>> The coverage plugins of which I'm aware are

>>>>> * Clover

>>>>> * jcoverage

>>>>> * Rational Developer (Unfortunately its coverage tools are part
>>>>> of its performance-testing tools, which complicates
>>>>> installation and use for "normal" testing.)

>>>>> Are there others?

"J. B. Rainsberger" Thu, 01 Sep 2005 22:33:36 -0400
>>>> Agitar's Agitator, which I finally saw for the first time this
>>>> past week. Impressive.

Indeed, it's so much more than just a coverage tool. (If I was Sam
Palmisano I'd buy them in a heartbeat, if only for the marketing
value--"Beck and Gamma ... together again!" :-)

Ilja Preuss Fri, 2 Sep 2005 08:11:51 +0200
>>> http://www.eclipse-plugins.info/eclipse/search.jsp?query=coverage

Doh! I wish I'd thoughta that--thanks!

Elliotte Harold Fri Sep 2, 2005 10:25 am
>> The only other option I know is Cobertura. There's no official
>> plugin, but the build file can make one. Whether it works or not, I
>> don't know. It could probably be made to work with a little
>> hacking.

Looks interesting, and didn't turn up in the above search, so I
submitted it via

http://eclipse-plugins.info/eclipse/pluginsubmit_form.jsp

Also one more: ConTest

http://www.alphaworks.ibm.com/tech/contest?open&S_TACT=105AGX59&S_CMP=GR&ca=dgr-lnxw03awcontest

has an eclipse plugin buried amidst the concurrency-testing tools.

Todd Bradley Fri Sep 2, 2005 2:34 pm
> we use EMMA on the projects I work on. It's not integrated with
> Eclipse, but it works well and is free. I haven't really found great
> need to integrate my coverage tool with my IDE, because of the way I
> use it. I'm usually interested in running a whole bunch of tests and
> then seeing how my coverage looks for the whole suite. Then, I drill
> down, notice I missed some methods or classes or whatever, and then
> go write tests for those.

Correct, and this is how those of us who use EMMA for BVT do it.
However I'd also like to have

>>>>> something more integrated, e.g.

>>>>> 0 a run config that would Run>{JUnit, JUnit Plug-in Test} under
>>>>> the coverage tool and display results in a view

>>>>> 1 mark un/covered sources in Outline view or editors

to give faster feedback.
